definition_en: To acquire or learn something, often gradually. Also means to improve or increase after a period of decline.

examples.sentence: She picked up the basics of accounting during her first week at the firm.

examples.grammar_note: picked up + noun phrase (object after particle)

examples.sentence: Picking up new software skills is essential for career advancement.

definition_en: To succeed in doing something difficult or unexpected. Often used when the outcome was uncertain.

examples.sentence: The team pulled off the product launch despite having only two weeks to prepare.
examples.grammar_note: pulled off + noun phrase (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: If we coordinate properly, we will pull off this merger without losing key staff.

examples.sentence: She is pulling off an incredibly complex restructuring of the entire division.
examples.grammar_note: is/are + pulling off + noun phrase

definition_en: To create or assemble something by combining different parts or elements. Commonly used for reports, teams, and plans.

examples.sentence: We put together a detailed proposal for the client over the weekend.
examples.context: preparing a pitch for a new client
examples.grammar_note: put together + noun phrase (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: The presentation is being put together by the marketing department right now.

examples.sentence: Put together a summary of the key findings and email it to the board.
examples.context: manager delegating tasks after a research phase
examples.grammar_note: base form as command + noun phrase

definition_en: To use up the entire supply of something so that none remains. Can refer to physical items, time, money, or abstract things like patience.

examples.sentence: Having run out of options, the board decided to accept the takeover bid.

definition_en: To increase the size, amount, or extent of something, especially a business operation or production process.

examples.sentence: Scaling up too quickly can strain a company's resources and culture.
examples.grammar_note: scaling up + adverb as gerund subject

definition_en: To distribute or dispatch something to multiple recipients. Commonly used for emails, invitations, or communications.

examples.sentence: The HR department sent out the updated employee handbook last Friday.
examples.grammar_note: sent out + noun phrase (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Please send out the meeting agenda at least 24 hours in advance.

examples.sentence: She is sending out the quarterly financial reports to all department heads today.

definition_en: To give formal approval or authorization for something. Also means to end a communication or broadcast.

examples.sentence: I will sign off now and follow up with you by email tomorrow.

definition_en: To register or enroll for something, such as a service, course, or event. Can also mean to recruit someone.

examples.sentence: Over fifty employees signed up for the leadership training workshop.
examples.grammar_note: signed up for + noun phrase (intransitive + preposition)

examples.sentence: Have you signed up for the annual company retreat yet?

examples.sentence: New clients are signing up for our premium service at a record rate.

examples.sentence: She would have signed up for the conference if it had not been so expensive.
examples.grammar_note: would have + signed up + if + Past Perfect

definition_en: To reduce speed or pace. In business, it means to decrease the rate of activity, growth, or progress.

definition_en: To increase the rate or pace of something. Used when a process, activity, or development needs to happen faster.

examples.sentence: We need to speed up the approval process to meet the launch deadline.

examples.sentence: The new automation software has sped up our order processing by 40%.

examples.sentence: Production was being sped up when the quality control issue was discovered.

definition_en: To be noticeably different or superior compared to others. To attract attention because of distinctive qualities.

definition_en: To give a brief summary of the main points. To describe something concisely.

examples.sentence: The chairman summed up the key decisions made during the board meeting.

examples.grammar_note: summed up + noun phrase (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Let me sum up the main findings before we move to the Q&A session.

examples.sentence: I need to take off early today because my flight to the conference leaves at six.

examples.grammar_note: need to + take off + adverb (informal: to leave)

definition_en: To consider something carefully before making a decision. To reflect on all aspects of an issue.

examples.sentence: We thought over the merger proposal carefully before giving our response.

examples.sentence: I need some time to think it over before committing to the partnership.

definition_en: To mention or deal with a subject briefly, without going into detail.

examples.sentence: The CEO briefly touched on the company's plans for international expansion.

definition_en: To make a failing business or situation successful again. Also means to complete a task within a specified time.

definition_en: To happen in a particular way or to have a particular result, especially one that was not expected.

examples.sentence: No one expected the restructuring to turn out so smoothly.

definition_en: To find a solution or resolve a problem through calculation or effort. Also means to develop or end in a satisfactory way.

examples.sentence: A few technical problems still need to be ironed out before the system goes live.

definition_en: To be good enough to meet a required standard or expectation. To compare favorably.

examples.sentence: The candidate did not measure up to the expectations set by the hiring panel.
examples.grammar_note: did not + measure up to + noun phrase (intransitive + preposition)

examples.sentence: Our customer service must measure up to industry-leading standards.
examples.grammar_note: must + measure up to + noun phrase

examples.sentence: The new supplier has measured up well against our quality benchmarks.
examples.grammar_note: has/have + measured up + adverb + against + noun phrase

examples.sentence: It remains to be seen whether the product will measure up to consumer expectations.
examples.grammar_note: whether + will + measure up to + noun phrase

definition_en: To create new opportunities or possibilities. Also means to begin operating a new business or to become more communicative.

examples.sentence: The trade agreement opened up new markets for domestic manufacturers.
examples.grammar_note: opened up + noun phrase + for + beneficiary

examples.sentence: New technologies are opening up opportunities that did not exist a decade ago.
examples.grammar_note: are/is + opening up + noun phrase + relative clause

examples.sentence: We plan to open up a regional office in Singapore by the end of the year.
examples.grammar_note: plan to + open up + noun phrase + by + time expression

examples.sentence: Once the new regulations are in place, the sector will open up to foreign investment.
examples.grammar_note: once + Present Simple, will + open up + to + noun phrase

definition_en: To choose to participate in something or to agree to be included in a scheme or programme.
translation_pl: zdecydować się na udział, wyrazić zgodę na włączenie

examples.sentence: Employees can opt in to the enhanced pension scheme during the enrollment period.
examples.grammar_note: can + opt in to + noun phrase + during + time expression

examples.sentence: Over 80% of staff have opted in to the flexible working arrangements.
examples.grammar_note: have/has + opted in to + noun phrase

examples.sentence: Users must actively opt in before their data can be shared with third parties.
examples.grammar_note: must + opt in + before + passive clause

examples.sentence: If you opted in to the programme last year, your enrolment renews automatically.
examples.tense: Past Simple (First Conditional with past reference)
examples.grammar_note: if + opted in to, Present Simple (factual conditional)

definition_en: To schedule something tentatively, with the understanding that it may change later.

examples.sentence: I have pencilled you in for a meeting at 3 p.m. on Thursday.
examples.context: scheduling an initial meeting with a client
examples.grammar_note: have + pencilled + person + in + for + time (separated)

examples.sentence: Let us pencil in a follow-up call for next week and confirm the details later.
examples.grammar_note: let us + pencil in + noun phrase + for + time

examples.sentence: The conference was pencilled in for June, but it may be moved to September.
examples.grammar_note: was + pencilled in + for + time (passive)

examples.sentence: Could you pencil in a slot for the quarterly review before the end of the month?
examples.context: assistant scheduling on behalf of a manager
examples.grammar_note: could + subject + pencil in + noun phrase (polite question)

definition_en: To contribute effort or help with a task, especially when working as part of a team. Similar to 'chip in' but with more emphasis on effort.

examples.sentence: The whole team pitched in to finish the report before the Friday deadline.
examples.context: end-of-week crunch to meet a deliverable
examples.grammar_note: pitched in + to + infinitive (purpose)

examples.sentence: If everyone pitches in, we can get the office ready for the client visit by noon.
examples.context: preparing for an important client visit
examples.grammar_note: if + Present Simple, can + base verb

examples.sentence: Even senior managers are pitching in with the preparations for the annual gala.
examples.grammar_note: are/is + pitching in + with + noun phrase

examples.sentence: She was happy to pitch in whenever extra help was needed on the project.
examples.grammar_note: happy to + pitch in + whenever + clause

definition_en: To increase or expand something rapidly, especially production, activity, or effort.

examples.sentence: The factory ramped up production to meet the holiday season demand.
examples.grammar_note: ramped up + noun phrase + to + infinitive (purpose)

examples.sentence: We have been ramping up our recruitment efforts to fill critical positions.
examples.grammar_note: have/has been + ramping up + noun phrase + to + infinitive

examples.sentence: Security measures will be ramped up ahead of the international summit.
examples.grammar_note: will be + ramped up + ahead of + noun phrase (passive)

examples.sentence: Ramping up too fast without adequate quality controls can damage the brand.
examples.grammar_note: ramping up + adverb + without + noun phrase (gerund subject)

definition_en: To tell someone about an idea or plan in order to get their opinion or approval.

examples.sentence: I ran the proposal by my manager before submitting it to the client.
examples.context: ensuring internal approval before client submission
examples.grammar_note: ran + noun phrase + by + person (separated: object between verb and particle)

examples.sentence: Can I run something by you quickly before the meeting starts?
examples.context: quick check with a colleague before a presentation
examples.grammar_note: can + subject + run + something + by + person (polite question)

examples.sentence: The legal team wants to run the contract terms by external counsel first.
examples.grammar_note: wants to + run + noun phrase + by + person

examples.sentence: You should have run the idea by the finance team before announcing it publicly.
examples.grammar_note: should have + run + noun phrase + by + person

definition_en: To sell all available stock of a product. Also means to abandon one's principles for personal gain.

examples.sentence: The limited edition collection sold out within hours of going on sale.
examples.grammar_note: sold out + within + time expression (intransitive)

examples.sentence: Tickets for the company's annual charity gala have already sold out.
examples.grammar_note: have/has + already + sold out (intransitive)

examples.sentence: If we do not increase production, the product will sell out before the holiday season.
examples.grammar_note: if + do not + base verb, will + sell out + before + time

examples.sentence: The event was completely sold out, so we had to arrange an overflow venue.
examples.grammar_note: was + sold out (passive/adjectival use)

definition_en: To assess or evaluate someone or something carefully in order to form a judgement.

examples.sentence: The investors sized up the startup before deciding whether to fund it.
examples.grammar_note: sized up + noun phrase + before + gerund clause

examples.sentence: She is sizing up the competition to identify gaps in their product offering.
examples.grammar_note: is/are + sizing up + noun phrase + to + infinitive

examples.sentence: The market opportunity needs to be sized up before we commit any resources.
examples.grammar_note: needs to be + sized up + before + clause (passive infinitive)

examples.sentence: Having sized up the situation, the negotiator adjusted her strategy accordingly.
examples.grammar_note: having + sized up + noun phrase (participle clause)

definition_en: To make a problem, disagreement, or difficult situation seem less serious or to resolve it diplomatically.

examples.sentence: The account manager smoothed over the dispute with the client by offering a discount.
examples.grammar_note: smoothed over + noun phrase + by + gerund (separable)

examples.sentence: It will take more than an apology to smooth over the damage caused by the data breach.
examples.tense: Infinitive (it will take + to + base form)
examples.grammar_note: it will take + noun + to + smooth over + noun phrase

examples.sentence: She has smoothed over tensions between the two departments on many occasions.
examples.grammar_note: has/have + smoothed over + noun phrase + on + frequency

examples.sentence: The situation cannot simply be smoothed over; it requires a formal investigation.
examples.context: compliance officer responding to misconduct allegations
examples.tense: Passive Voice (modal: cannot + be + past participle)
examples.grammar_note: cannot + be + smoothed over (passive with negative modal)

definition_en: To define or claim a position, territory, or area of interest. To establish one's stance clearly.

examples.sentence: The company staked out its position as the market leader in sustainable packaging.
examples.grammar_note: staked out + noun phrase + as + role/identity

examples.sentence: We are staking out new territory in the fintech space with our latest product.
examples.grammar_note: are/is + staking out + noun phrase + in + area + with + means

examples.sentence: Each division has staked out its own area of expertise within the broader organization.
examples.grammar_note: has/have + staked out + noun phrase + within + context

examples.sentence: To stake out a competitive advantage, the firm invested heavily in R&D.
examples.context: annual report narrative on innovation strategy
examples.grammar_note: to + stake out + noun phrase (infinitive of purpose) + main clause

definition_en: To end a romantic relationship. Also, to separate into smaller parts or pieces.

examples.sentence: They broke up after five years of dating.
examples.context: telling a friend about a couple's separation
examples.grammar_note: intransitive use — no direct object

examples.sentence: She has broken up with her boyfriend and moved back home.
examples.context: sharing recent personal news with a colleague
examples.grammar_note: phrasal verb + with + object (break up with someone)

examples.sentence: If you keep arguing like this, you will break up sooner or later.
examples.context: warning a friend about relationship problems
examples.grammar_note: conditional-style prediction with will + base form

examples.sentence: The ice on the lake is breaking up as spring arrives.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive use — literal meaning of separating into pieces

definition_en: To cause something to happen. Often used for significant changes or events.

examples.sentence: The new policy brought about major improvements in employee satisfaction.
examples.context: reviewing the effects of a workplace policy
examples.grammar_note: transitive — separable phrasal verb with noun object after particle

examples.sentence: Technology has brought about enormous changes in how we communicate.
examples.context: discussing social trends in a class debate
examples.grammar_note: transitive with noun phrase as direct object

examples.sentence: The reforms are expected to bring about lasting economic stability.
examples.context: political commentary in a newspaper article
examples.grammar_note: passive voice (be expected to) + infinitive

examples.sentence: Bringing about real change requires patience and persistence.
examples.grammar_note: gerund as subject of the sentence

definition_en: To become less agitated, anxious, or emotional. Also used transitively to help someone else relax.

examples.sentence: He calmed down after taking a few deep breaths.
examples.context: describing how someone managed stress before an exam
examples.grammar_note: intransitive use — no object needed

examples.sentence: Calm down and think about this rationally.
examples.context: advising an upset friend during an argument
examples.grammar_note: imperative mood — direct command

examples.sentence: She has been trying to calm the children down all afternoon.
examples.context: a parent dealing with overexcited kids at a party
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: If you calmed down, you would see the situation more clearly.
examples.context: giving advice during a heated discussion
examples.grammar_note: conditional clause with past tense for hypothetical present

definition_en: To reach the same level or position as someone who is ahead. Also, to spend time learning about things you missed.

examples.sentence: I was behind on the project, but I caught up over the weekend.
examples.context: explaining progress on a work assignment
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — used with adverbial phrase of time

examples.sentence: We should catch up for coffee sometime next week.
examples.context: suggesting a social meeting with an old friend
examples.grammar_note: modal should + base form for suggestion

examples.sentence: She has finally caught up with the rest of the class after being ill.
examples.context: teacher updating a parent about a student's progress
examples.grammar_note: phrasal verb + with + object (catch up with someone)

examples.sentence: He is catching up on all the episodes he missed during his holiday.
examples.context: talking about watching a TV series
examples.grammar_note: phrasal verb + on (catch up on something)

definition_en: To examine or look at something interesting. Also, to leave a hotel or to pay and leave a shop.

examples.sentence: We checked out of the hotel at ten o'clock this morning.
examples.context: describing departure from accommodation while travelling
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + preposition of (check out of a place)

examples.sentence: You should check out that new restaurant on the corner.
examples.context: recommending a place to a friend
examples.grammar_note: modal should + base form for strong recommendation

examples.sentence: Have you checked out the new art exhibition at the gallery?
examples.context: asking about a cultural event in town
examples.grammar_note: transitive — direct object after the particle

examples.sentence: Guests must check out before noon or they will be charged extra.
examples.grammar_note: modal must + base form expressing obligation

definition_en: To make a place tidy by removing dirt or mess. Also, to remove unwanted elements from something.

examples.sentence: We cleaned up the entire kitchen after the dinner party.
examples.grammar_note: transitive — direct object after particle

examples.sentence: The beach is being cleaned up by volunteers this Saturday.
examples.context: community announcement about an environmental event
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — is being + past participle

examples.sentence: If everyone helps, we will clean up in no time.
examples.context: motivating a group to tidy a shared space
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present, will + base form

examples.sentence: He had cleaned up the mess before his parents arrived.
examples.context: teenager tidying after a party before parents come home
examples.grammar_note: past perfect for an action completed before another past event

definition_en: To return to a place where you were before. Also, to become popular or fashionable again.

examples.sentence: She came back from her trip feeling completely refreshed.
examples.context: describing how someone felt after a holiday
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + from + noun (indicating origin)

examples.sentence: Vinyl records have come back into fashion in recent years.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — figurative use meaning to become popular again

examples.sentence: Will you come back before dinner or should I eat without you?
examples.context: asking a family member about their plans
examples.grammar_note: yes/no question with will — asking about future plans

examples.sentence: I was coming back from the shop when I saw the accident.
examples.context: reporting an incident to a friend
examples.grammar_note: past continuous for background action interrupted by another event

definition_en: To draw a line through written words to show they are wrong or no longer needed.

examples.sentence: She crossed out her old address and wrote the new one above it.
examples.context: updating personal details on a form
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: Cross out any items on the list that you have already completed.
examples.context: instructions for managing a to-do list
examples.grammar_note: imperative with direct object after particle

examples.sentence: Several names had been crossed out before the final version was printed.
examples.context: reviewing a document with prior edits
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — had been + past participle

examples.sentence: He is crossing out the incorrect answers on his exam paper.
examples.context: student correcting mistakes during a test
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle in progressive form

definition_en: To stop the supply of something, such as electricity or water. Also, to interrupt someone who is speaking.

examples.sentence: The electricity was cut off because they hadn't paid the bill.
examples.context: explaining why a household lost power
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — was + past participle

examples.sentence: Please don't cut me off — let me finish what I'm saying.
examples.context: asking someone not to interrupt during a conversation
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative with pronoun between verb and particle

examples.sentence: The village has been cut off from the main road by heavy flooding.
examples.context: news report about a natural disaster
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — has been + past participle + from

examples.sentence: If they cut off our internet, we won't be able to work from home.
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + base form

definition_en: To do something again from the beginning, usually because it was done incorrectly the first time.

examples.sentence: The teacher asked him to do the assignment over because of too many errors.
examples.context: school situation where work needs to be redone
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: If I could do it over, I would choose a different university.
examples.grammar_note: conditional with could + base form for hypothetical past

examples.sentence: The entire project will have to be done over from scratch.
examples.context: manager delivering bad news about a failed project
examples.grammar_note: passive voice with modal — will have to be + past participle

examples.sentence: She has done the report over three times and it's still not perfect.
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle with adverb

definition_en: To wear formal or fancy clothes. Also, to wear a costume or disguise.

examples.sentence: Everyone dressed up for the New Year's Eve gala.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — no object needed

examples.sentence: The children are dressing up as superheroes for the school play.
examples.context: preparing for a costume event at school
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + as (dress up as something)

examples.sentence: You don't need to dress up — it's a casual dinner.
examples.context: reassuring a guest about a dress code
examples.grammar_note: negative with need to + base form

examples.sentence: She had dressed up the room with fairy lights and balloons before the guests arrived.
examples.context: decorating a space for a birthday party
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — figurative meaning to decorate

definition_en: To have a meal at a restaurant or somewhere other than at home.
translation_pl: jeść na mieście; jeść w restauracji

examples.sentence: We ate out at a lovely Italian place last Friday.
examples.context: telling a friend about a recent dinner experience
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + at + place

examples.sentence: They have been eating out almost every night since the kitchen renovation started.
examples.context: explaining why someone spends a lot on food
examples.grammar_note: continuous form emphasising duration of repeated action

examples.sentence: Shall we eat out tonight or cook something at home?
examples.context: making plans for the evening with a partner
examples.grammar_note: shall for suggestion/offer in question form

examples.sentence: Eating out every day can become quite expensive.
examples.grammar_note: gerund as subject of the sentence

definition_en: To break into pieces or stop working properly. Also used figuratively when something or someone collapses emotionally.
translation_pl: rozpadać się; rozlecieć się; załamać się

examples.sentence: The old bookcase finally fell apart after years of use.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — no object; literal meaning

examples.sentence: Their marriage has been falling apart for months.
examples.grammar_note: continuous form emphasising ongoing deterioration

examples.sentence: If the deal falls apart, we'll need to find another buyer.
examples.context: discussing contingency plans in a business context
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + base form

examples.sentence: She was falling apart emotionally after hearing the terrible news.
examples.context: describing someone's reaction to a shocking event
examples.grammar_note: past continuous for ongoing emotional state — figurative meaning

definition_en: To complete a form, questionnaire, or document by writing the required information.

examples.sentence: Please fill out this application form and return it to the front desk.
examples.context: receptionist giving instructions to a visitor
examples.grammar_note: imperative with direct object after particle

examples.sentence: She filled out the visa application without making a single mistake.
examples.grammar_note: transitive — direct object after particle

examples.sentence: All the forms must be filled out before the interview begins.
examples.context: HR process for new job candidates
examples.grammar_note: passive voice with modal must — must be + past participle

examples.sentence: Have you filled out the survey that was sent to you by email?
examples.context: following up on a customer feedback request
examples.grammar_note: yes/no question in present perfect with relative clause

definition_en: To discover or learn new information, often something that was previously unknown or hidden.

examples.sentence: We found out that the flight had been cancelled when we arrived at the airport.
examples.grammar_note: transitive + that-clause as object

examples.sentence: She is trying to find out who is responsible for the leak.
examples.grammar_note: trying to + find out + embedded wh-clause

examples.sentence: If he finds out the truth, he will be furious.
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + adjective

examples.sentence: I had already found out about the surprise party before they told me.
examples.context: recounting how a secret was revealed too early
examples.grammar_note: past perfect + about + noun phrase

definition_en: To escape from a place or a person. Also, to go somewhere for a holiday or break.
translation_pl: uciec; wyrwać się (na wakacje); oddalić się

examples.sentence: The thief got away before the police arrived.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — no object needed

examples.sentence: We need to get away for a few days — I'm completely exhausted.
examples.context: suggesting a short holiday to a partner
examples.grammar_note: need to + base form expressing necessity

examples.sentence: She has gotten away with being late to class so many times.
examples.context: commenting on someone who avoids consequences
examples.grammar_note: phrasal verb + with + gerund (get away with doing something)

examples.sentence: If we had left earlier, we would have gotten away from the traffic.
examples.context: regretting not leaving sooner for a road trip
examples.grammar_note: third conditional — if + past perfect, would have + past participle

definition_en: To manage to survive or live with difficulty, especially with limited money or resources.
translation_pl: dawać sobie radę; wiązać koniec z końcem

examples.sentence: They got by on a single income while she was studying.
examples.context: describing financial hardship during university years
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + on + noun phrase (source of income)

examples.sentence: We can get by without a car if we use public transport.
examples.context: discussing ways to reduce household expenses
examples.grammar_note: modal can + base form + without + noun

examples.sentence: She has been getting by with freelance work until she finds a permanent job.
examples.grammar_note: continuous form + with + noun phrase

examples.sentence: If prices keep rising, many families won't be able to get by.
examples.context: discussing the impact of inflation on society
examples.grammar_note: first conditional with negative — won't be able to + base form

definition_en: To recover from an illness, shock, or emotional upset. Also, to overcome a difficulty.
translation_pl: dojść do siebie; pogodzić się z czymś; przejść (chorobę)

examples.sentence: It took him weeks to get over the flu.
examples.grammar_note: it takes + person + time + to + infinitive

examples.sentence: She still hasn't gotten over the loss of her dog.
examples.context: talking about grief and emotional recovery
examples.grammar_note: negative present perfect with still for emphasis

examples.sentence: You'll get over it eventually — everyone goes through tough times.
examples.context: consoling a friend after a breakup
examples.grammar_note: will + base form for reassurance about the future

examples.sentence: Getting over your fear of public speaking takes practice.
examples.grammar_note: gerund phrase as subject of the sentence

definition_en: To rise from bed after sleeping. Also, to stand up from a sitting or lying position.

examples.sentence: I got up at six o'clock to catch the early train.
examples.context: explaining a morning routine on a workday
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + at + time expression

examples.sentence: She usually gets up before everyone else in the family.
examples.grammar_note: adverb of frequency + present simple for habitual action

examples.sentence: He was getting up from his chair when the phone rang.
examples.context: narrating a sequence of events at home
examples.grammar_note: past continuous interrupted by past simple event

examples.sentence: If you got up earlier, you wouldn't always be late for work.
examples.context: giving advice to someone with punctuality issues
examples.grammar_note: second conditional — if + past simple, would + base form

definition_en: To give something to someone for free. Also, to reveal a secret or hidden information accidentally.

examples.sentence: She gave away all her old clothes to charity.
examples.context: describing a decluttering effort at home
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle + to + recipient

examples.sentence: Don't give the ending away — I haven't seen the film yet!
examples.context: asking someone not to spoil a movie
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative with object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: The company has given away thousands of free samples this month.
examples.context: marketing promotion for a new product
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle with quantifier

examples.sentence: His nervous smile was giving away the fact that he was lying.
examples.context: noticing someone's dishonesty through body language
examples.grammar_note: past continuous — ongoing action revealing something gradually

definition_en: To stop trying to do something because it is too difficult. Also, to quit a habit or activity.

examples.sentence: He gave up smoking ten years ago and hasn't touched a cigarette since.
examples.context: talking about overcoming a bad habit
examples.grammar_note: transitive — gerund as direct object (give up doing something)

examples.sentence: Never give up on your dreams, no matter how hard things get.
examples.context: motivational advice to a younger person
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative + on + noun (give up on something)

examples.sentence: She has given up trying to convince him to change his mind.
examples.context: describing someone's resignation after many attempts
examples.grammar_note: present perfect + gerund complement (give up trying)

examples.sentence: If I were you, I wouldn't give up so easily.
examples.context: encouraging a friend who feels defeated
examples.grammar_note: second conditional with if I were you for advice

definition_en: To return to a place you were before. Also, to return to a previous topic or point in time.
translation_pl: wracać; cofnąć się (do tematu, w czasie)

examples.sentence: We went back to the same hotel we stayed at five years ago.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + to + place

examples.sentence: I would love to go back to Japan someday.
examples.context: expressing a travel wish in conversation
examples.grammar_note: would love to + base form for wishes

examples.sentence: Let's go back to what you were saying about the budget.
examples.context: redirecting a meeting discussion to a previous point
examples.grammar_note: let's + base form for suggestion

examples.sentence: Their friendship goes back to when they were in primary school.
examples.context: describing the length of a long friendship
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + to — figurative meaning of dating back

definition_en: To continue doing something or to happen. Also, to proceed to the next thing.

examples.sentence: The meeting went on for three hours without a break.
examples.context: complaining about a long meeting at work
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + for + duration

examples.sentence: Please go on — I didn't mean to interrupt.
examples.context: apologising for cutting in during a conversation
examples.grammar_note: imperative — polite request to continue

examples.sentence: What's going on over there? I can hear a lot of noise.
examples.grammar_note: wh-question with continuous form — meaning to happen

examples.sentence: She had gone on talking even after the bell rang.
examples.context: describing a teacher who continued past the end of class
examples.grammar_note: past perfect + gerund (go on doing something — continue)

definition_en: To leave home for entertainment or social activities. Also, when a light or fire stops burning.

examples.sentence: We went out for dinner and a movie last Saturday night.
examples.context: talking about weekend plans with friends
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + for + noun (purpose)

examples.sentence: She doesn't go out as much as she used to since the baby was born.
examples.context: discussing lifestyle changes after becoming a parent
examples.grammar_note: negative + comparative structure (as much as)

examples.sentence: The candle had gone out by the time we got back to the room.
examples.context: noticing a change after returning to a place
examples.grammar_note: past perfect — literal meaning of a flame extinguishing

examples.sentence: Are you going out tonight or staying in?
examples.context: asking a flatmate about evening plans
examples.grammar_note: present continuous for near-future plans — or-question

definition_en: To develop from a child into an adult. Also used to tell someone to behave more maturely.

examples.sentence: He grew up in a small village in the south of Poland.
examples.context: sharing childhood background with new friends
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + in + place

examples.sentence: Oh, grow up! You're acting like a five-year-old.
examples.context: telling someone to stop being childish
examples.grammar_note: imperative — used to scold someone for immature behaviour

examples.sentence: Children who grow up bilingual often find it easier to learn additional languages.
examples.context: discussing language development in an educational context
examples.grammar_note: relative clause with who + present simple for general truth

examples.sentence: By the time you see them again, the kids will have grown up so much.
examples.context: commenting on how quickly children change
examples.grammar_note: future perfect — will have + past participle for completion by a future time

definition_en: To spend time relaxing or socialising in a casual way, often without a specific plan.

examples.sentence: We hung out at the park all afternoon doing nothing.
examples.context: describing a lazy day with friends
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + at + place

examples.sentence: She has been hanging out with her university friends a lot lately.
examples.grammar_note: continuous + with + person for ongoing social activity

examples.sentence: Do you want to hang out this weekend?
examples.context: casually inviting a friend to spend time together
examples.grammar_note: do you want to + infinitive for informal invitation

examples.sentence: They were hanging out at the cafe when the rainstorm started.
examples.context: narrating events during a sudden change of weather
examples.grammar_note: past continuous for background activity interrupted by an event

definition_en: To end a phone call by putting the phone down or pressing a button. Also, to put something on a hook or hanger.

examples.sentence: She hung up the phone before I could say goodbye.
examples.context: describing an abruptly ended phone call
examples.grammar_note: transitive — direct object after particle

examples.sentence: Don't hang up — I have one more thing to tell you.
examples.context: trying to keep someone on the phone
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative — intransitive use

examples.sentence: He always hangs up his coat as soon as he gets home.
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: If she hangs up on me again, I won't call back.
examples.context: expressing frustration about someone's phone behaviour
examples.grammar_note: first conditional + hang up on someone (ending call rudely)

definition_en: To leave a place and start going somewhere. A casual way of saying to depart.

examples.sentence: We headed out early in the morning to avoid the traffic.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + adverb of time

examples.sentence: I'm heading out now — see you later!
examples.context: saying goodbye to colleagues at the end of the day
examples.grammar_note: present continuous for immediate action

examples.sentence: What time are you planning to head out tomorrow?
examples.grammar_note: planning to + base form for future arrangement

examples.sentence: We should head out before it gets dark.
examples.context: suggesting departure while hiking in the countryside
examples.grammar_note: modal should + base form for suggestion with time clause

definition_en: To delay or cause a delay. Also, to raise something for others to see, or to rob a place using threats.
translation_pl: opóźniać; wstrzymywać; podnosić (do góry); napadać (na bank)

examples.sentence: The heavy rain held up traffic for over two hours.
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle

examples.sentence: Sorry I'm late — I was held up at the office.
examples.context: apologising for arriving late to a dinner
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — was + past participle

examples.sentence: Could you hold up that document so everyone can see it?
examples.context: asking someone to display something during a meeting
examples.grammar_note: polite request with could + base form — literal meaning

examples.sentence: The project has been held up due to a lack of funding.
examples.context: explaining delays in a business project
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — has been + past participle + due to

definition_en: To do something more quickly or to move faster. Often used to urge someone to be quicker.

examples.sentence: Hurry up or we'll miss the bus!
examples.context: rushing a family member in the morning
examples.grammar_note: imperative + or + consequence clause

examples.sentence: She hurried up and finished packing just in time.
examples.context: getting ready for a trip at the last moment
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + and + coordinated clause

examples.sentence: I wish they would hurry up — we've been waiting for an hour.
examples.context: expressing impatience while waiting for friends
examples.grammar_note: wish + would + base form for desire about others' behaviour

examples.sentence: He was hurrying up to get everything ready before the guests arrived.
examples.context: preparing for a dinner party under time pressure
examples.grammar_note: past continuous + to-infinitive of purpose

definition_en: To stay at a distance from something or someone. Also, to prevent someone from coming near.
translation_pl: trzymać się z daleka; trzymać z dala (od czegoś/kogoś)

examples.sentence: Keep away from the edge — it's dangerous!
examples.context: warning someone near a cliff while hiking
examples.grammar_note: imperative + from + noun (source of danger)

examples.sentence: The fence keeps wild animals away from the garden.
examples.context: explaining the purpose of a garden fence
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: She had kept away from sugary food for months before her diet failed.
examples.context: describing a failed attempt at healthy eating
examples.grammar_note: past perfect + from + noun for duration before another event

examples.sentence: If you keep away from negative people, you'll feel much happier.
examples.context: giving life advice to a friend
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + base form

definition_en: To make someone unconscious, especially by hitting them. Also, to eliminate someone from a competition.

examples.sentence: The boxer knocked out his opponent in the third round.
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle

examples.sentence: Our team was knocked out of the tournament in the semi-finals.
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — was + past participle + out of

examples.sentence: The sleeping pill will knock you out for at least eight hours.
examples.context: doctor explaining the effect of medication
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — pronoun between verb and particle

examples.sentence: That spicy food really knocked me out — I fell asleep on the sofa.
examples.context: joking about feeling sleepy after a heavy meal
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — figurative informal meaning

definition_en: To not include something or someone, either intentionally or by mistake.

examples.sentence: You left out an important detail in your report.
examples.context: pointing out a missing element in a work document
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle

examples.sentence: Make sure no one is left out of the invitation list.
examples.context: organising a team event at work
examples.grammar_note: passive voice with make sure — is + past participle + of

examples.sentence: She always feels left out when her friends make plans without her.
examples.context: describing someone who feels excluded socially
examples.grammar_note: feels + past participle used as adjective

examples.sentence: Several key figures had been left out of the documentary.
examples.context: reviewing a historical film and noting omissions
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — had been + past participle + of

definition_en: To allow someone or something to enter a place.

examples.sentence: Could you let me in? I forgot my keys.
examples.context: asking a flatmate to open the door
examples.grammar_note: polite request with could — pronoun between verb and particle

examples.sentence: The security guard let us in after checking our tickets.
examples.context: entering a venue for a concert
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — pronoun between verb and particle + after + gerund

examples.sentence: Don't let the cat in — she'll make a mess.
examples.context: warning someone not to open the door for a pet
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative with object between verb and particle

examples.sentence: If we hadn't been let in early, we would have missed the opening act.
examples.context: discussing how lucky it was to enter a show early
examples.grammar_note: third conditional passive — if + past perfect passive, would have + past participle

definition_en: To put yourself in a flat, horizontal position, usually on a bed or the floor.

examples.sentence: I need to lie down for a few minutes — I have a terrible headache.
examples.context: feeling unwell and wanting to rest
examples.grammar_note: need to + base form expressing necessity

examples.sentence: She lay down on the sofa and fell asleep almost immediately.
examples.context: describing someone resting after a long day
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + on + place (note irregular past: lay)

examples.sentence: The doctor told him to lie down and rest for at least two days.
examples.context: medical advice after a minor procedure
examples.grammar_note: reported speech with to-infinitive (told someone to do something)

examples.sentence: The dog is lying down in the shade to escape the heat.
examples.context: observing a pet's behaviour on a hot day
examples.grammar_note: present continuous + to-infinitive of purpose

definition_en: To take care of someone or something by keeping them safe, healthy, or in good condition.

examples.sentence: She looked after her elderly mother for several years.
examples.context: describing a period of caregiving within a family
examples.grammar_note: inseparable phrasal verb + direct object

examples.sentence: Who is looking after the children while you're at work?
examples.grammar_note: wh-question with present continuous

examples.sentence: Can you look after my plants while I'm on holiday?
examples.context: asking a neighbour for a favour before travelling
examples.grammar_note: polite request with can + base form

examples.sentence: The house had been well looked after by the previous owners.
examples.context: commenting on the condition of a property during a viewing
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — had been + adverb + past participle

definition_en: To try to find something or someone by searching or investigating.

examples.sentence: I've been looking for my car keys all morning.
examples.context: frustrated about a lost item before leaving the house
examples.grammar_note: continuous form emphasising duration of the search

examples.sentence: She is looking for a new job in the tech industry.
examples.grammar_note: inseparable phrasal verb + direct object

examples.sentence: What exactly are you looking for in a candidate?
examples.context: HR interview question about ideal qualifications
examples.grammar_note: wh-question with preposition at the end

examples.sentence: They looked for the missing dog for three days before finding it.
examples.context: telling a story about a lost pet
examples.grammar_note: past simple + for + duration + before + gerund

definition_en: To feel excited and happy about something that is going to happen in the future.
translation_pl: nie móc się doczekać; cieszyć się na (coś)

examples.sentence: I'm really looking forward to the summer holidays.
examples.context: expressing excitement about upcoming time off
examples.grammar_note: inseparable three-word phrasal verb + noun

examples.sentence: We look forward to hearing from you soon.
examples.context: closing line in a formal email
examples.grammar_note: formal use + gerund (look forward to + -ing)

examples.sentence: She had been looking forward to the concert for months before it was cancelled.
examples.context: expressing disappointment about a cancelled event
examples.grammar_note: past perfect continuous emphasising duration before a past event

examples.sentence: Are you looking forward to starting your new job next week?
examples.context: asking a friend about an upcoming career change
examples.grammar_note: yes/no question + gerund as object of the preposition to

definition_en: To search for information in a reference source such as a dictionary, book, or the internet.

examples.sentence: I looked up the word in the dictionary because I didn't know the meaning.
examples.context: studying vocabulary while reading a book
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle + in + source

examples.sentence: You can look it up online if you're not sure about the answer.
examples.grammar_note: modal can + pronoun between verb and particle

examples.sentence: She has been looking up flights to Barcelona all evening.
examples.context: planning a trip by browsing the internet
examples.grammar_note: continuous form + object after particle

examples.sentence: Things are finally looking up after a really difficult year.
examples.context: expressing optimism about an improving situation
examples.grammar_note: intransitive — figurative meaning of improving

definition_en: To manage to see, hear, or understand something with difficulty. Also, to claim or pretend something is the case.

examples.sentence: I couldn't make out what he was saying because of the noise.
examples.context: struggling to hear someone in a loud environment
examples.grammar_note: could not + base form + wh-clause

examples.sentence: She is trying to make out the small text on the medicine bottle.
examples.grammar_note: trying to + base form + direct object

examples.sentence: He made himself out to be an expert, but he knew very little.
examples.context: describing someone who exaggerated their abilities
examples.grammar_note: reflexive + out + to be (make oneself out to be something)

examples.sentence: Can you make out that sign in the distance?
examples.context: driving and trying to read a road sign from far away
examples.grammar_note: modal can + transitive with object after particle

definition_en: To confuse two or more things or people with each other. Also, to put things in the wrong order.

examples.sentence: I always mix up their names because they look so alike.
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle

examples.sentence: The documents got mixed up during the move to the new office.
examples.grammar_note: passive-like structure with get + past participle

examples.sentence: She had mixed up the dates and arrived a day early for the appointment.
examples.grammar_note: past perfect — action before another past event

examples.sentence: Be careful not to mix up the salt and the sugar when you're baking.
examples.context: giving cooking advice to a beginner
examples.grammar_note: be careful not to + base form — warning

definition_en: To start living in a new home or to begin occupying a new space.

examples.sentence: They moved in together after dating for two years.
examples.context: a couple starting to share a home
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + together — adverb of manner

examples.sentence: We are moving in next Friday, so there's a lot to organise.
examples.grammar_note: present continuous for planned future event

examples.sentence: She has already moved in and started decorating her new flat.
examples.context: updating friends about a recent relocation
examples.grammar_note: present perfect with already + coordinated clause

examples.sentence: Once we move in, we'll need to set up the internet immediately.
examples.context: planning practical steps for a new home
examples.grammar_note: time clause with once + present simple, main clause with will

definition_en: To leave a home or place where you have been living and go somewhere else.

examples.sentence: He moved out of his parents' house when he turned eighteen.
examples.context: describing a young person becoming independent
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + out of + place

examples.sentence: She is moving out at the end of the month because the rent is too high.
examples.context: explaining a decision to leave a rental property
examples.grammar_note: present continuous for planned future event + because clause

examples.sentence: If the neighbours don't stop making noise, I'll move out.
examples.context: threatening to leave due to noise problems
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + base form

examples.sentence: By the time the new tenants arrive, we will have moved out completely.
examples.context: planning the transition between tenants in a flat
examples.grammar_note: future perfect — will have + past participle with by-clause

definition_en: To die. This is a polite, indirect way of saying that someone has died.

examples.sentence: Her grandfather passed away peacefully in his sleep last night.
examples.context: sharing sad news about a family member's death
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + adverb of manner

examples.sentence: It has been five years since he passed away, and we still miss him.
examples.context: remembering a loved one on an anniversary
examples.grammar_note: it has been + time + since + past simple

examples.sentence: When her mother passed away, the whole community came together to support her.
examples.grammar_note: when-clause + past simple in both clauses

examples.sentence: Many traditions are passing away as younger generations adopt new customs.
examples.context: discussing cultural change in a sociological context
examples.grammar_note: figurative meaning — traditions disappearing over time

definition_en: To lose consciousness or faint. Also, to distribute items to a group of people.

examples.sentence: He passed out from the heat and had to be taken to hospital.
examples.context: describing a medical incident on a hot day
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + from + cause

examples.sentence: The teacher is passing out the exam papers to the students.
examples.context: distributing tests at the beginning of an exam
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle + to + recipient

examples.sentence: If you don't drink enough water, you might pass out during the marathon.
examples.grammar_note: first conditional with might instead of will for possibility

examples.sentence: She had passed out on the sofa after working a double shift.
examples.grammar_note: past perfect — figurative meaning of falling into deep sleep

definition_en: To return money that you owe to someone. Also, to take revenge on someone for something they did.

examples.sentence: I'll pay you back as soon as I get my salary.
examples.context: promising to return borrowed money to a friend
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — pronoun between verb and particle

examples.sentence: She paid back the entire loan within two years.
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle + within + time frame

examples.sentence: The money must be paid back by the end of the month.
examples.grammar_note: passive voice with modal — must be + past participle

examples.sentence: He has been paying back his student debt for over ten years.
examples.context: discussing the burden of educational loans
examples.grammar_note: continuous form emphasising duration of ongoing repayment

definition_en: To choose or select something from a group or collection.

examples.sentence: She picked out a beautiful dress for the wedding.
examples.context: shopping for a special occasion outfit
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle

examples.sentence: Can you help me pick out a birthday gift for my sister?
examples.context: asking for help choosing a present
examples.grammar_note: help + object + base form + phrasal verb

examples.sentence: The winners will be picked out from the entries by a panel of judges.
examples.context: explaining the selection process for a competition
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — will be + past participle + from

examples.sentence: He had already picked out the restaurant before I even suggested going out.
examples.grammar_note: past perfect with already — action completed before another past event

definition_en: To connect an electrical device to a power supply by inserting a plug into a socket.

examples.sentence: Don't forget to plug in your phone before you go to bed.
examples.context: reminding someone to charge their device
examples.grammar_note: negative imperative with don't forget to + base form

examples.sentence: She plugged in the laptop and started working immediately.
examples.context: setting up a workspace at a cafe
examples.grammar_note: transitive — object after particle + coordinated clause

examples.sentence: The speaker isn't working because it hasn't been plugged in.
examples.context: troubleshooting audio equipment before a presentation
examples.grammar_note: passive voice — hasn't been + past participle

examples.sentence: Once you plug it in, the device will automatically start updating.
examples.context: explaining how to set up a new gadget
examples.grammar_note: time clause with once + present simple, will + base form

definition_en: To appear suddenly or unexpectedly. Also used for windows or messages that appear on a screen.

examples.sentence: A strange error message popped up on my screen while I was working.
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + on + location

examples.sentence: New coffee shops keep popping up all over the neighbourhood.
examples.context: commenting on changes in a local area
examples.grammar_note: keep + gerund for repeated ongoing action

examples.sentence: He has a habit of popping up when you least expect it.
examples.grammar_note: have a habit of + gerund

examples.sentence: An opportunity like this won't just pop up again anytime soon.
examples.context: urging someone to seize an opportunity
examples.grammar_note: negative future with won't + just for emphasis

definition_en: To remove something from inside a place or container. Also, to withdraw from an activity, agreement, or commitment.

examples.sentence: He pulled out his wallet and paid for everyone's dinner.
examples.context: a generous gesture at a restaurant
examples.grammar_note: transitive separable — object after particle

examples.sentence: The company has pulled out of the deal due to financial concerns.
examples.context: business news about a cancelled agreement
examples.grammar_note: intransitive + out of (withdraw from something)

examples.sentence: If the main investor pulls out, the entire project will collapse.
examples.context: discussing risks in a business meeting
examples.grammar_note: first conditional — if + present simple, will + base form

examples.sentence: She was pulling out of the driveway when she noticed the flat tyre.
examples.grammar_note: past continuous for background action + when clause — literal driving meaning

definition_en: To place something in its proper storage location. Also means to save money for future use.

examples.sentence: She put away all the dishes after dinner.
examples.context: tidying the kitchen after a meal
examples.grammar_note: subject + put away + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: I've been putting away a little money each month for a holiday.
examples.context: saving money over a period of time
examples.grammar_note: have been + putting away + object (continuous aspect for ongoing action)

examples.sentence: Put your toys away before you go outside!
examples.context: parent instructing a child to tidy up
examples.grammar_note: imperative + object + away (separated form with object between verb and particle)

examples.sentence: The groceries will be put away by the time you get home.
examples.context: promising to finish a household task
examples.grammar_note: will be + past participle (passive voice, future)

definition_en: To place clothing or accessories on your body. Also means to start a device or to stage an event.

examples.sentence: He put on his jacket and left the house.
examples.context: getting ready to go outside in cold weather
examples.grammar_note: subject + put on + object (inseparable in this usage)

examples.sentence: She is putting on a brave face despite the bad news.
examples.context: hiding emotions in a difficult situation
examples.grammar_note: is + putting on + noun phrase (idiomatic expression)

examples.sentence: The school has put on a wonderful play this year.
examples.context: a school producing a theatrical performance
examples.grammar_note: has + past participle + object (present perfect for recent event)

examples.sentence: You should put on some sunscreen before going to the beach.
examples.grammar_note: should + put on + object (modal verb for advice)

definition_en: To extinguish a fire or light. Also means to publish or release something, or to inconvenience someone.

examples.sentence: The firefighters put out the blaze within an hour.
examples.context: emergency response to a building fire
examples.grammar_note: subject + put out + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: The company has put out a statement regarding the incident.
examples.context: a business issuing an official response
examples.grammar_note: has + put out + object (present perfect for recent action with current relevance)

examples.sentence: I hope I'm not putting you out by arriving so early.
examples.context: a guest worried about inconveniencing the host
examples.grammar_note: am not + putting out + object (continuous for current action)

examples.sentence: Make sure the campfire is put out before you leave.
examples.grammar_note: is + past participle (passive imperative construction)

definition_en: To tolerate or endure something unpleasant without complaining.

examples.sentence: She put up with his bad behaviour for years before leaving.
examples.grammar_note: subject + put up with + object (three-part inseparable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: I can't put up with this noise any longer!
examples.grammar_note: can't + put up with + object (modal verb for inability)

examples.sentence: They have been putting up with poor service for months.
examples.context: customers frustrated with a utility provider
examples.grammar_note: have been + putting up with (continuous for ongoing situation)

examples.sentence: Why should we put up with such unfair treatment?
examples.context: questioning an unjust policy at work
examples.grammar_note: should + put up with (modal in rhetorical question)

definition_en: To leave a place quickly in order to escape from someone or something.

examples.sentence: The dog ran away when the fireworks started.
examples.context: a pet frightened by loud noises
examples.grammar_note: subject + ran away + time clause (intransitive phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Don't run away from your problems; face them.
examples.context: encouraging someone to deal with difficulties
examples.grammar_note: don't + run away + from (negative imperative with preposition)

examples.sentence: He has run away from home three times this year.
examples.context: a troubled teenager leaving home repeatedly
examples.grammar_note: has + past participle + frequency adverb (present perfect for repeated past actions)

examples.sentence: If I saw a bear, I would probably run away immediately.
examples.context: imagining an encounter with a wild animal
examples.grammar_note: would + run away (second conditional for hypothetical situation)

definition_en: To hit someone or something with a vehicle. Also means to exceed an allotted time or to review something quickly.

examples.sentence: A car nearly ran over the cat on our street last night.
examples.context: a dangerous incident involving a pet
examples.grammar_note: subject + ran over + object (separable, but kept together here)

examples.sentence: The meeting is running over by twenty minutes.
examples.context: a meeting exceeding its scheduled time
examples.grammar_note: is + running over + by (continuous for action happening now)

examples.sentence: Could we run over the main points one more time?
examples.context: requesting a quick review before a presentation
examples.grammar_note: could + run over + object (polite request with modal)

examples.sentence: The details had been run over briefly before the final decision was made.
examples.context: reviewing information prior to an important choice
examples.grammar_note: had been + past participle (past perfect passive)

definition_en: To begin a journey. Also means to cause something to explode or to trigger an alarm or reaction.

examples.sentence: We set off early in the morning to avoid the traffic.
examples.context: starting a road trip at dawn
examples.grammar_note: subject + set off + adverb of time (intransitive, no object needed)

examples.sentence: The smoke from the kitchen has set off the fire alarm.
examples.context: cooking accident triggering a safety device
examples.grammar_note: has + set off + object (present perfect for result visible now)

examples.sentence: They will be setting off for Paris tomorrow afternoon.
examples.grammar_note: will be + setting off (future continuous for planned arrangement)

examples.sentence: Setting off firecrackers in the city centre is strictly prohibited.
examples.context: a public safety regulation about fireworks
examples.grammar_note: gerund as subject + is + adjective (gerund clause as subject of sentence)

definition_en: To become calm and quiet after a period of excitement. Also means to start living a stable, routine life, often in one place.
translation_pl: uspokajać się; osiedlać się; ustatkować się

examples.sentence: The children eventually settled down after the party.
examples.grammar_note: subject + settled down + time adverb (intransitive phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: He's thinking about settling down and buying a house.
examples.grammar_note: thinking about + settling down (gerund after preposition)

examples.sentence: Once you have settled down in your new city, invite us to visit.
examples.grammar_note: once + present perfect (time clause for future completion)

examples.sentence: Settle down, everyone — the lesson is about to begin.
examples.context: a teacher addressing a noisy classroom
examples.grammar_note: imperative form + vocative (direct command)

definition_en: To behave in a way that is intended to attract attention and impress others. Also means to display something proudly.

examples.sentence: He was showing off his new car to all the neighbours.
examples.grammar_note: was + showing off + object (continuous for ongoing past action)

examples.sentence: Stop showing off — nobody is impressed.
examples.context: telling someone their boasting is unwelcome
examples.grammar_note: stop + gerund (imperative with gerund complement)

examples.sentence: She has always shown off her cooking skills at family gatherings.
examples.context: someone who regularly demonstrates talent at events
examples.grammar_note: has always + past participle (present perfect with frequency adverb)

examples.sentence: The new gallery will show off the artist's latest collection.
examples.context: an upcoming exhibition at a gallery
examples.grammar_note: will + show off + object (future simple for scheduled event)

definition_en: To arrive or appear at a place, sometimes unexpectedly. Also means to become visible or to embarrass someone by performing better.

examples.sentence: He showed up at the party without being invited.
examples.context: an unexpected guest at a social event
examples.grammar_note: subject + showed up + prepositional phrase (intransitive)

examples.sentence: She hasn't shown up for work in three days.
examples.grammar_note: hasn't + past participle + duration (present perfect negative)

examples.sentence: If he doesn't show up by noon, we'll leave without him.
examples.context: waiting for a late friend before a trip
examples.grammar_note: if + present simple, will + infinitive (first conditional)

examples.sentence: The stain kept showing up even after several washes.
examples.context: trying to remove a mark from clothing
examples.grammar_note: kept + gerund (past simple with 'keep' + gerund for repeated action)

definition_en: To stop operating or to close a business, machine, or system completely.

examples.sentence: The factory was shut down due to safety violations.
examples.grammar_note: was + past participle + reason clause (passive with due to)

examples.sentence: Please shut down your computer before leaving the office.
examples.context: an office instruction at the end of the day
examples.grammar_note: imperative + object + time clause (polite command)

examples.sentence: The website has been shutting down intermittently all week.
examples.context: recurring technical problems with a server
examples.grammar_note: has been + shutting down + adverb (continuous for repeated interruptions)

examples.sentence: If sales continue to drop, they will shut down the branch.
examples.context: a business considering closing a location
examples.grammar_note: if + present simple, will + shut down (first conditional)

definition_en: To move from a standing position to a seated one. Also used to mean having a serious discussion.

examples.sentence: Please sit down and make yourself comfortable.
examples.context: welcoming a guest into your home
examples.grammar_note: imperative + coordinated clause (polite instruction)

examples.sentence: We sat down together and discussed the problem calmly.
examples.grammar_note: subject + sat down + adverb (intransitive with coordinated verbs)

examples.sentence: I was just sitting down to eat when the phone rang.
examples.grammar_note: was + sitting down + when clause (interrupted action in the past)

examples.sentence: We need to sit down with the team and sort this out.
examples.context: planning a meeting to resolve an issue at work
examples.grammar_note: need + to sit down + with (infinitive of purpose)

definition_en: To rise to a standing position from sitting or lying down. Also means to defend or support something, or to fail to meet someone as planned.
translation_pl: wstawać; stawać w obronie; wystawić kogoś (nie przyjść na spotkanie)

examples.sentence: Everyone stood up when the judge entered the courtroom.
examples.context: showing respect in a legal setting
examples.grammar_note: subject + stood up + when clause (intransitive with time clause)

examples.sentence: You should stand up for what you believe in.
examples.context: encouraging someone to defend their values
examples.grammar_note: should + stand up for (modal verb for advice with preposition)

examples.sentence: He has stood her up twice — she won't give him another chance.
examples.context: someone repeatedly failing to show up for a date
examples.grammar_note: has + past participle + object + frequency adverb (transitive, informal meaning)

examples.sentence: Standing up too quickly can make you feel dizzy.
examples.grammar_note: gerund as subject + can + infinitive (gerund clause as subject)

definition_en: To continue doing or using something and not change to anything else. To follow a plan, promise, or decision without deviating.

examples.sentence: She stuck to her diet even during the holiday season.
examples.grammar_note: subject + stuck to + object (inseparable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Let's stick to the agenda so we finish on time.
examples.context: keeping a meeting focused and efficient
examples.grammar_note: let's + stick to + object (suggestion with let's)

examples.sentence: He has always stuck to his principles, no matter what.
examples.context: describing someone with strong moral character
examples.grammar_note: has always + past participle (present perfect with adverb of frequency)

examples.sentence: If you stick to the plan, everything will work out fine.
examples.grammar_note: if + present simple, will + infinitive (first conditional)

definition_en: To remove something from a place or person. Also means to subtract, or to buy food to eat elsewhere.

examples.sentence: The waiter took away our plates before we had finished.
examples.context: dining at a restaurant with rushed service
examples.grammar_note: subject + took away + object + time clause (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Nothing can take away the joy of that moment.
examples.grammar_note: nothing + can + take away + object (modal with negative subject)

examples.sentence: The key message to take away from this lecture is the importance of practice.
examples.context: summarising the main point of a lesson
examples.grammar_note: to take away + from (infinitive as modifier of noun)

examples.sentence: Two pizzas had been taken away by the previous customers.
examples.context: ordering food at a busy pizzeria
examples.grammar_note: had been + past participle (past perfect passive)

definition_en: To return something to where it came from. Also means to retract a statement or to accept a returned item.

examples.sentence: I took the faulty product back to the shop for a refund.
examples.context: returning a defective item to a store
examples.grammar_note: subject + took + object + back (separated form)

examples.sentence: He refuses to take back what he said about her.
examples.context: someone stubbornly standing by hurtful comments
examples.grammar_note: refuses + to take back + object clause (infinitive complement)

examples.sentence: That song really takes me back to my university days.
examples.context: a piece of music evoking old memories
examples.grammar_note: subject + takes + pronoun + back (idiomatic: to evoke nostalgia)

examples.sentence: If I could take back those words, I would.
examples.grammar_note: if + could + infinitive (second conditional for regret)

definition_en: To remove something from a place. Also means to go on a date with someone, to obtain an official document, or to order food for eating elsewhere.
translation_pl: wyjmować; zabrać (kogoś gdzieś); wykupić (polisę); zamawiać na wynos

examples.sentence: He took out his wallet and paid for the meal.
examples.context: paying the bill at a restaurant
examples.grammar_note: subject + took out + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: She's been taking out a new insurance policy for her car.
examples.grammar_note: has been + taking out (continuous for a process in progress)

examples.sentence: I'd like to take you out for dinner this Friday.
examples.grammar_note: would like + to take out + object (polite offer with would)

examples.sentence: Don't forget to take out the rubbish before you go to bed.
examples.context: a household reminder in the evening
examples.grammar_note: don't forget + to take out + object (imperative with infinitive)

definition_en: To consider something carefully or to have something in your mind. To reflect on a subject before making a decision.
translation_pl: myśleć o; zastanawiać się nad; rozważać

examples.sentence: I've been thinking about changing careers recently.
examples.grammar_note: have been + thinking about + gerund (continuous for ongoing reflection)

examples.sentence: She thought about his offer for days before accepting.
examples.grammar_note: subject + thought about + object + duration (past simple with time phrase)

examples.sentence: Think about what you really want before you decide.
examples.context: advising someone to reflect before acting
examples.grammar_note: imperative + about + wh-clause (command with embedded question)

examples.sentence: It's worth thinking about the long-term consequences.
examples.context: urging caution in a planning discussion
examples.grammar_note: it's worth + gerund (fixed expression with gerund)

definition_en: To discard something by putting it in the bin. Also means to waste an opportunity or advantage.

examples.sentence: She threw away all the expired food from the fridge.
examples.grammar_note: subject + threw away + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Don't throw away this opportunity — it won't come again.
examples.context: encouraging someone to seize a rare chance
examples.grammar_note: don't + throw away + object (negative imperative)

examples.sentence: Tons of plastic are thrown away every single day around the world.
examples.grammar_note: are + past participle (present passive for general truth)

examples.sentence: He had thrown away the receipt, so he couldn't return the item.
examples.context: regretting the disposal of an important document
examples.grammar_note: had + past participle (past perfect for earlier of two past actions)

definition_en: To put on a piece of clothing to see if it fits or suits you before buying it.

examples.sentence: She tried on five dresses before finding the perfect one.
examples.context: shopping for a special occasion outfit
examples.grammar_note: subject + tried on + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: Can I try this jacket on in a larger size?
examples.context: asking a shop assistant for help
examples.grammar_note: can + subject + try + object + on (question with separated verb and particle)

examples.sentence: He is trying on shoes at the moment and will be out shortly.
examples.context: waiting for someone in a shoe shop
examples.grammar_note: is + trying on + object (continuous for action in progress)

examples.sentence: I would recommend trying on several options before you decide.
examples.grammar_note: recommend + gerund (verb + gerund complement)

definition_en: To test something to see how well it works or how much you like it.

examples.sentence: We tried out the new restaurant on the corner last weekend.
examples.context: testing a recently opened dining place
examples.grammar_note: subject + tried out + object (separable phrasal verb)

examples.sentence: I've been trying out different recipes for banana bread.
examples.grammar_note: have been + trying out (continuous for ongoing experimentation)

examples.sentence: Would you like to try out the software before purchasing it?
examples.context: a salesperson offering a product demonstration
examples.grammar_note: would like + to try out (polite offer with infinitive)
